</div>
<!-- End AdSlot 1 -->
</div>

<p>Here, are certain situations when you better not use Fuzzy Logic:</p>
<ul>
<li>If you don&#8217;t find it convenient to map an input space to an output space</li>
<li>Fuzzy logic should not be used when you can use common sense</li>
<li>Many controllers can do the fine job without the use of fuzzy logic</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="5" data-lasso-id="198422" href="#"></a>Fuzzy Logic Architecture</h2>
<p><center></p>
<figure>
<img width="1299" height="497" src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%201299%20497'%3E%3C/svg%3E" alt="Fuzzy Logic Architecture" data-lazy-src="https://www.guru99.com/images/1/110218_0659_FuzzyLogicT1.png"><noscript><img width="1299" height="497" src="https://www.guru99.com/images/1/110218_0659_FuzzyLogicT1.png" alt="Fuzzy Logic Architecture"></noscript></p>
<p class="img_caption">Fuzzy Logic Architecture</p>
</figure>
<p></center></p>
<p>Fuzzy Logic architecture has four main parts as shown in the diagram:</p>
<h3>Rule Base:</h3>
<p>It contains all the rules and the if-then conditions offered by the experts to control the decision-making system. The recent update in fuzzy theory provides various methods for the design and tuning of fuzzy controllers. This updates significantly reduce the number of the fuzzy set of rules.</p>
<h3>Fuzzification:</h3>
<p>Fuzzification step helps to convert inputs. It allows you to convert, crisp numbers into fuzzy sets. Crisp inputs measured by sensors and passed into the control system for further processing. Like Room temperature, pressure, etc.</p>
<h3>Inference Engine:</h3>
<p>It helps you to determines the degree of match between fuzzy input and the rules. Based on the % match, it determines which rules need implment according to the given input field. After this, the applied rules are combined to develop the control actions.</p>
<h3>Defuzzification:</h3>
<p>At last the Defuzzification process is performed to convert the fuzzy sets into a crisp value. There are many types of techniques available, so you need to select it which is best suited when it is used with an expert system.</p>
<h2><a id="6" data-lasso-id="198423" href="#"></a>Fuzzy Logic vs. Probability</h2>
<table class="table table-striped">
<tbody>
<tr>
<th>Fuzzy Logic</th>
<th>Probability</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Fuzzy: Tom&#8217;s degree of membership within the set of old people is 0.90.</td>
<td>Probability: There is a 90% chance that Tom is old.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Fuzzy logic takes truth degrees as a mathematical basis on the model of the vagueness phenomenon.</td>
<td>Probability is a mathematical model of ignorance.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2><a id="7" data-lasso-id="198424" href="#"></a>Crisp vs. Fuzzy</h2>
<table class="table table-striped">
<tbody>
<tr>
<th>Crisp</th>
<th>Fuzzy</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>It has strict boundary T or F</td>
<td>Fuzzy boundary with a degree of membership</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Some crisp time set can be fuzzy</td>
<td>It can&#8217;t be crisp</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>True/False {0,1}</td>
<td>Membership values on [0,1]</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>In Crisp logic law of Excluded Middle and Non- Contradiction may or may not hold</td>
<td>In the fuzzy logic law of Excluded Middle and Non- Contradiction hold</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2><a id="8" data-lasso-id="198425" href="#"></a>Classical Set vs. Fuzzy set Theory</h2>
<table class="table table-striped">
<tbody>
<tr>
<th>Classical Set</th>
<th>Fuzzy Set Theory</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Classes of objects with sharp boundaries.</td>
<td>Classes of objects do not have sharp boundaries.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>A classical set is defined by crisp boundaries, i.e., there is clarity about the location of the set boundaries.</td>
<td>A fuzzy set always has ambiguous boundaries, i.e., there may be uncertainty about the location of the set boundaries.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>Widely used in digital system design</td>
<td>Used only in fuzzy controllers.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2><a id="9" data-lasso-id="198426" href="#"></a>Fuzzy Logic Examples</h2>
<p>See the below-given diagram. It shows that in a Fuzzy system, the values are denoted by a 0 to 1 number. In this example, 1.0 means absolute truth and 0.0 means absolute falseness.</p>
<p><center></p>
<figure>
<img width="308" height="303" src="data:image/svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%20308%20303'%3E%3C/svg%3E" alt="Fuzzy Logic with Example" data-lazy-src="https://www.guru99.com/images/1/110218_0659_FuzzyLogicT2.png"><noscript><img width="308" height="303" src="https://www.guru99.com/images/1/110218_0659_FuzzyLogicT2.png" alt="Fuzzy Logic with Example"></noscript></p>
<p class="img_caption">Fuzzy Logic with Example</p>
</figure>
<p></center></p>
<h2><a id="10" data-lasso-id="198427" href="#"></a>Application Areas of Fuzzy Logic</h2>
<p>The Blow given table shows application of Fuzzy logic by famous companies in their products.</p>
<table class="table table-striped">
<tbody>
<tr>
<th class="vs-sticky">Product</th>
<th>Company</th>
<th>Fuzzy Logic</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="vs-sticky">Anti-lock brakes</td>
<td>Nissan</td>
<td>Use fuzzy logic to controls brakes in hazardous cases depend on car speed, acceleration, wheel speed, and acceleration</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="vs-sticky">Auto transmission</td>
<td>NOK/Nissan</td>
<td>Fuzzy logic is used to control the fuel injection and ignition based on throttle setting, cooling water temperature, RPM, etc.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="vs-sticky">Auto engine</td>
<td>Honda, Nissan</td>
<td>Use to select geat based on engine load, driving style, and road conditions.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="vs-sticky">Copy machine</td>
<td>Canon</td>
<td>Using for adjusting drum voltage based on picture density, humidity, and temperature.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="vs-sticky">Cruise control</td>
<td>Nissan, Isuzu, Mitsubishi</td>
<td>Use it to adjusts throttle setting to set car speed and acceleration</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="vs-sticky">Dishwasher</td>
<td>Matsushita</td>
<td>Use for adjusting the cleaning cycle, rinse and wash strategies based depend upon the number of dishes and the amount of food served on the dishes.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="vs-sticky">Elevator control</td>
<td>Fujitec, Mitsubishi Electric, Toshiba</td>
<td>Use it to reduce waiting for time-based on passenger traffic</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="vs-sticky">Golf diagnostic system</td>
<td>Maruman Golf</td>
<td>Selects golf club based on golfer&#8217;s swing and physique.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="vs-sticky">Fitness management</td>
<td>Omron</td>
<td>Fuzzy rules implied by them to check the fitness of their employees.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="vs-sticky">Kiln control</td>
<td>Nippon Steel</td>
<td>Mixes cement</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="vs-sticky">Microwave oven</td>
<td>Mitsubishi Chemical</td>
<td>Sets lunes power and cooking strategy</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="vs-sticky">Palmtop computer</td>
<td>Hitachi, Sharp, Sanyo, Toshiba</td>
<td>Recognizes handwritten Kanji characters</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td class="vs-sticky">Plasma etching</td>
<td>Mitsubishi Electric</td>
<td>Sets etch time and strategy</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2><a id="11" data-lasso-id="198428" href="#"></a>Advantages of Fuzzy Logic System</h2>
<ul>
<li>The structure of Fuzzy Logic Systems is easy and understandable</li>
<li>Fuzzy logic is widely used for commercial and practical purposes</li>
<li>Fuzzy logic in AI helps you to control machines and consumer products</li>
<li>It may not offer accurate reasoning, but the only acceptable reasoning</li>
<li>Fuzzy logic in Data Mining helps you to deal with the uncertainty in engineering</li>
<li>Mostly robust as no precise inputs required</li>
<li>It can be programmed to in the situation when feedback sensor stops working</li>
<li>It can easily be modified to improve or alter system performance</li>
<li>inexpensive sensors can be used which helps you  to keep the overall system cost and  complexity low</li>
<li>It provides a most effective solution to complex issues</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="12" data-lasso-id="198429" href="#"></a>Disadvantages of Fuzzy Logic Systems</h2>
<ul>
<li>Fuzzy logic is not always accurate, so The results are perceived based on assumption, so it may not be widely accepted.</li>
<li>Fuzzy systems don&#8217;t have the capability of machine learning as-well-as neural network type pattern recognition</li>
<li>Validation and Verification of a fuzzy knowledge-based system needs  extensive testing with hardware</li>
<li>Setting exact, fuzzy rules and, membership functions is a difficult task</li>
<li>Some fuzzy time logic is confused with probability theory and the terms</li>
</ul>
<h2>Summary</h2>
<ul>
<li>The term fuzzy mean things which are not very clear or vague</li>
<li>The term fuzzy logic was first used with 1965 by Lotfi Zadeh a professor of UC Berkeley in California</li>
<li>Fuzzy logic is a flexible and easy to implement machine learning technique</li>
<li>Fuzzy logic should not be used when you can use common sense</li>
<li>Fuzzy Logic architecture has four main parts 1) Rule Basse 2) Fuzzification 3) Inference  Engine 4) Defuzzification</li>
<li>Fuzzy logic takes truth degrees as a mathematical basis on the model of the vagueness while probability is a mathematical model of ignorance</li>
<li>Crisp set has strict boundary T or F while Fuzzy boundary with a degree of membership</li>
<li>A classical set is widely used in digital system design while fuzzy set Used only in fuzzy controllers</li>
<li>Auto transmission, Fitness management, Golf diagnostic system, Dishwasher, Copy machine are some areas of Fuzzy Logic applications</li>
<li>Fuzzy logic in Soft Computing helps you to control machines and consumer products</li>
</ul><div class='yarpp yarpp-related yarpp-related-website yarpp-template-list'>

(max-width:991px){.postCard__author{display:none;}}@media screen and (max-width:991px){#breadcrumbs li span,#breadcrumbs li{line-height:42px;}}</style> <link rel="shortcut icon" href="https://cdn-fjjdg.nitrocdn.com/EvUiFcmIZmdwYVghMNwzGtDLNxywSmVk/assets/static/optimized/rev-1edddb4/wp-content/themes/cfemedia/assets/images/src/favicon-controleng.ico" />  <script type="application/ld+json" class="saswp-schema-markup-output">
[{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Person","name":"","description":"","url":"","sameAs":[],"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/?s=96&d=mm&r=g","height":96,"width":96},"address":{"@type":"PostalAddress"}},

{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"Article","@id":"https://www.controleng.com/articles/artificial-intelligence-fuzzy-logic-explained/#Article","url":"https://www.controleng.com/articles/artificial-intelligence-fuzzy-logic-explained/","inLanguage":"en-US","mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.controleng.com/articles/artificial-intelligence-fuzzy-logic-explained/","headline":"Artificial Intelligence: Fuzzy Logic Explained","description":"Fuzzy logic is not as fuzzy as you might think and has been working quietly behind the scenes for more than 20 years in more places than most admit. Fuzzy logic is a rule-based system that can rely on the practical experience of an operator, particularly useful to capture experienced operator knowledge. Fuzzy logic is","articleBody":"Fuzzy logic is not as fuzzy as you might think and has been working quietly behind the scenes for more than 20 years in more places than most admit. Fuzzy logic is a rule-based system that can rely on the practical experience of an operator, particularly useful to capture experienced operator knowledge. Fuzzy logic is a form of artificial intelligence software; therefore, it would be considered a subset of AI. Since it is performing a form of decision making, it can be loosely included as a member of the AI software toolkit. Here’s what you need to know to consider using fuzzy logic to help solve your next application. It’s not as fuzzy as you might think.  Fuzzy logic has been around since the mid 1960s; however, it was not until the 70s that a practical application was demonstrated. Since that time the Japanese have traditionally been the largest producer of fuzzy logic applications. Fuzzy logic has appeared in cameras, washing machines, and even in stock trading applications. In the last decade the United States has started to catch on to the use of fuzzy logic. There are many applications that use fuzzy logic, but fail to tell us of its use. Probably the biggest reason is that the term “fuzzy logic” may have a negative connotation.  Fuzzy logic can be applied to non-engineering applications as illustrated in the stock trading application. It has also been used in medical diagnosis systems and in handwriting recognition applications. In fact a fuzzy logic system can be applied to almost any type of system that has inputs and outputs.  Fuzzy logic systems are well suited to nonlinear systems and systems that have multiple inputs and multiple outputs. Any reasonable number of inputs and outputs can be accommodated. Fuzzy logic also works well when the system cannot be modeled easily by conventional means.  Many engineers are afraid to dive into fuzzy logic due to a lack of understanding. Fuzzy logic does not have to be hard to understand, even though the math behind it can be intimidating, especially to those of us who have not been in a math class for many years.  Binary logic is either 1 or 0. Fuzzy logic is a continuum of values between 0 and 1. This may also be thought of as 0% to 100%. An example is the variable YOUNG. We may say that age 5 is 100% YOUNG, 18 is 50% YOUNG, and 30 is 0% YOUNG. In the binary world everything below 18 would be 100% YOUNG, and everything above would be 0% YOUNG.  The design of a fuzzy logic system starts with a set of membership functions for each input and a set for each output. A set of rules is then applied to the membership functions to yield a “crisp” output value.  For this process control explanation of fuzzy logic, TEMPERATURE is the input and FAN SPEED is the output. Create a set of membership functions for each input. A membership function is simply a graphical representation of the fuzzy variable sets. For this example, use three fuzzy sets, COLD, WARM, and HOT. We will then create a membership function for each of three sets of temperature as shown in the cold-normal-hot graphic, Figure 1.   Figure 1  We will use three fuzzy sets for the output, SLOW, MEDIUM, and FAST. A set of functions is created for each output set just as for the input sets.   Figure 2  It should be noted that the shape of the membership functions do not need to be triangles as we have used in Figure 1 and Figure 2. Various shapes that can be used, such as Trapezoid, Gaussian, Sigmoid, or user definable. By changing the shape of the membership function, the user can tune the system to provide optimum response.  Now that we have our membership functions defined, we can create the rules that will define how the membership functions will be applied to the final system. We will create three rules for this system.   If HOT then FAST If WARM then MEDIUM If COLD then SLOW  The rules are then applied to the membership functions to produce the “crisp” output value to drive the system. For simplicity we will illustrate using only two input and two output functions. For an input value of 52 degrees we intersect the membership functions. We see that in this example the intersection will be on both functions, thus two rules are applied. The intersection points are extended to the output functions to produce an intersecting point. The output functions are then truncated at the height of the intersecting points. The area under the curves for each membership function is then added to give us a total area. The centroid of this area is calculated. The output value is then the centroid value. In this example 44% is the output FAN SPEED value. This process is illustrated in Figure 3.   Figure 3  This is a very simple explanation of how the fuzzy logic systems work. In a real working system, there would be many inputs and possibility several outputs. This would result in a fairly complex set of functions and many more rules. It is not uncommon for there to be 40 or more rules in a system. Even so, the principles remain the same as in our simple system.  National Instruments has included in LabVIEW a set of pallet functions and a fuzzy system designer to greatly simplify the task of building a fuzzy logic system. It has included several demo programs in the examples to get started. In the graphical environment, the user can easily see what the effects are as the functions and rules are built and changed.  The user should remember that a fuzzy logic system is not a “silver bullet” for all control system needs. Traditional control methods are still very much a viable solution. In fact they may be combined with fuzzy logic to produce a dynamically changing system. The validation of a fuzzy logic system can be difficult due to the fact that it is a nonformal system. Its use in safety systems should be considered with care.  I hope this short article will inspire the exploration and use of fuzzy logic in some of your future designs. I encourage the reader to do further study on the subject. There are numerous books and articles that go into much more detail. This serves as a simple introduction to fuzzy logic controls.  - Norm Dingle is a senior system engineer with EMP Technical Group of Noblesville, IN. Engineers</a></li> <li id="menu-item-38239" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-38239"><a href="https://www.oilandgaseng.com">Oil &#038; Gas Engineering</a></li> </li> <li id="menu-item-38218" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-has-children menu-item-38218"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="#">System Integrators</a> <ul class="sub-menu"> <li id="menu-item-47447" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-47447"><a target="_blank" href="https://gspplatform.cfemedia.com/si/home">Global System Integrator Database</a></li> <li id="menu-item-47448" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-47448"><a href="https://www.controleng.com/supplement/global-system-integrator-report-digital-supplement/">Global System Integrator Report</a></li> <li id="menu-item-47449" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-47449"><a href="https://www.controleng.com/events-and-awards/system-integrator-giants/">System Integrator Giants</a></li> <li id="menu-item-47450" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-47450"><a href="https://www.controleng.com/events-and-awards/system-integrator-of-the-year-program/">System Integrator of the Year</a></li> <li id="menu-item-47451" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom <li> <a href="https://www.controleng.com/"> <span>Home</span> </a> <meta content="1" /> </li> <li> <a href="https://www.controleng.com/process-manufacturing/"> <span>Process Manufacturing</span> </a> <meta content="2" /> </li> <li> <a href="https://www.controleng.com/articles/artificial-intelligence-fuzzy-logic-explained/"> <span>Artificial Intelligence: Fuzzy Logic Explained</span> </a> <meta content="3" /> </li> </ol> </div> <main class="frame" id="app"> <div class="frame__container"> <section class="frame__primary"> <div class="singlePost singlePost--article "> <h1 class="singlePost__title"> Artificial Intelligence: Fuzzy Logic Explained </h1> <h2 class="singlePost__subtitle"> Fuzzy logic for most of us: It’s not as fuzzy as you might think and has been working quietly behind the scenes for years. Fuzzy logic is a rule-based system that can rely on the practical experience of an operator, particularly useful to capture experienced operator knowledge. Here’s what you need to know. </h2> <div class="singlePost__meta"> <span class="singlePost__author">By <a href="/author/">Norm Dingle</a> </span> <span class="singlePost__date">November 4, 2011</span> L34.6666667,62.5333333 L21.3333333,62.5333333 L21.3333333,19.8666667 Z"></path> </svg> <span class="screen-reader-text">LinkedIn</span> </a> </li> <li data-service="email"> <a 31.7083333,4.66974432 31.125,5.52201705 C30.5416667,6.37428977 29.8154762,7.10227273 28.9464286,7.70596591 C24.4702381,10.7954545 21.6845238,12.7189867 20.5892857,13.4765625 C20.4702381,13.5594223 C14.7678571,15.6427557 14.4255952,15.4829545 14.0625,15.2698864 C13.6994048,15.0568182 13.389881,14.864465 13.1339286,14.6928267 C12.8779762,14.5211884 12.5565476,14.2962831 12.1696429,14.0181108 C11.7827381,13.7399384 11.5297619,13.5594223 11.4107143,13.4765625 C10.327381,12.7189867 8.76785714,11.6388494 6.73214286,10.2361506 C4.69642857,8.8334517 3.47619048,7.99005682 3.07142857,7.70596591 C2.33333333,7.20880682 1.63690476,6.52521307 0.982142857,5.65518466 C0.327380952,4.78515625 0,3.97727273 0,3.23153409 C0,2.30823864 0.24702381,1.53882576 0.741071429,0.923295455 C1.23511905,0.307765152 1.94047619,0 2.85714286,0 L29.1428571,0 C29.9166667,0 30.5863095,0.278172348 31.1517857,0.834517045 C31.7172619,1.39086174 32,2.05965909 32,2.84090909 Z"></path> </svg> <span class="screen-reader-text">Email</span> </a> </li> </ul> </nav> <div class="singlePost__content"> <p> Fuzzy logic is not as fuzzy as you might think and has been working quietly behind the scenes for more than 20 years in more places than most admit. Fuzzy logic is a rule-based system that can rely on the practical experience of an operator, particularly useful to capture experienced operator knowledge. Fuzzy logic is a form of artificial intelligence software; therefore, it would be considered a subset of AI. Since it is performing a form of decision making, it can be loosely included as a member of the AI software toolkit. Here’s what you need to know to consider using fuzzy logic to help solve your next application. It’s not as fuzzy as you might think. </p> <p>Fuzzy logic has been around since the mid 1960s; however, it was not until the 70s that a practical application was demonstrated. Since that time the Japanese have traditionally been the largest producer of fuzzy logic applications. Fuzzy logic has appeared in cameras, washing machines, and even in stock trading applications. In the last decade the United States has started to catch on to the use of fuzzy logic. There are many applications that use fuzzy logic, but fail to tell us of its use. Probably the biggest reason is that the term “fuzzy logic” may have a negative connotation. </p> <div class="advertisement advertisement-paragraph-300x50" style="display:none;" data-zone-tag="300x50" data-zone-id="8073" data-zone-context="mobile" data-revive-id="5d3cba222eaaeee40162c5d04d22e1b8"><ins data-revive-zoneid="" data-revive-id=""></ins></div><div class="advertisement advertisement-paragraph-desktop-728x90" style="display:none;" data-zone-tag="728x90" data-zone-id="8075" data-zone-context="desktop" data-revive-id="5d3cba222eaaeee40162c5d04d22e1b8"><ins data-revive-zoneid="" data-revive-id=""></ins></div><p>Fuzzy logic can be applied to non-engineering applications as illustrated in the stock trading application. It has also been used in medical diagnosis systems and in handwriting recognition applications. In fact a fuzzy logic system can be applied to almost any type of system that has inputs and outputs. </p> <p>Fuzzy logic systems are well suited to nonlinear systems and systems that have multiple inputs and multiple outputs. Any reasonable number of inputs and outputs can be accommodated. Fuzzy logic also works well when the system cannot be modeled easily by conventional means. </p> <div class="advertisement advertisement-paragraph-300x250" style="display:none;" data-zone-tag="300x250" data-zone-id="8691" data-zone-context="mobile" data-revive-id="5d3cba222eaaeee40162c5d04d22e1b8"><ins data-revive-zoneid="" data-revive-id=""></ins></div><p>Many engineers are afraid to dive into fuzzy logic due to a lack of understanding. Fuzzy logic does not have to be hard to understand, even though the math behind it can be intimidating, especially to those of us who have not been in a math class for many years. </p> <p>Binary logic is either 1 or 0. Fuzzy logic is a continuum of values between 0 and 1. This may also be thought of as 0% to 100%. An example is the variable YOUNG. We may say that age 5 is 100% YOUNG, 18 is 50% YOUNG, and 30 is 0% YOUNG. In the binary world everything below 18 would be 100% YOUNG, and everything above would be 0% YOUNG. </p> <p>The design of a fuzzy logic system starts with a set of membership functions for each input and a set for each output. A set of rules is then applied to the membership functions to yield a “crisp” output value. </p> <p>For this process control explanation of fuzzy logic, TEMPERATURE is the input and FAN SPEED is the output. Create a set of membership functions for each input. A membership function is simply a graphical representation of the fuzzy variable sets. For this example, use three fuzzy sets, COLD, WARM, and HOT. We will then create a membership function for each of three sets of temperature as shown in the cold-normal-hot graphic, Figure 1. </p> <p></p> <p>Figure 1 </p> <p>We will use three fuzzy sets for the output, SLOW, MEDIUM, and FAST. A set of functions is created for each output set just as for the input sets. </p> <p></p> <p>Figure 2 </p> <p>It should be noted that the shape of the membership functions do not need to be triangles as we have used in Figure 1 and Figure 2. Various shapes that can be used, such as Trapezoid, Gaussian, Sigmoid, or user definable. By changing the shape of the membership function, the user can tune the system to provide optimum response. </p> <p>Now that we have our membership functions defined, we can create the rules that will define how the membership functions will be applied to the final system. We will create three rules for this system. </p> <ul> <li>If HOT then FAST</li> <li>If WARM then MEDIUM</li> <li>If COLD then SLOW</li> </ul> <p>The rules are then applied to the membership functions to produce the “crisp” output value to drive the system. For simplicity we will illustrate using only two input and two output functions. For an input value of 52 degrees we intersect the membership functions. We see that in this example the intersection will be on both functions, thus two rules are applied. The intersection points are extended to the output functions to produce an intersecting point. The output functions are then truncated at the height of the intersecting points. The area under the curves for each membership function is then added to give us a total area. The centroid of this area is calculated. The output value is then the centroid value. In this example 44% is the output FAN SPEED value. This process is illustrated in Figure 3. </p> <p></p> <p>Figure 3 </p> <p>This is a very simple explanation of how the fuzzy logic systems work. In a real working system, there would be many inputs and possibility several outputs. This would result in a fairly complex set of functions and many more rules. It is not uncommon for there to be 40 or more rules in a system. Even so, the principles remain the same as in our simple system. </p> <p>National Instruments has included in LabVIEW a set of pallet functions and a fuzzy system designer to greatly simplify the task of building a fuzzy logic system. It has included several demo programs in the examples to get started. In the graphical environment, the user can easily see what the effects are as the functions and rules are built and changed. </p> <p>The user should remember that a fuzzy logic system is not a “silver bullet” for all control system needs. Traditional control methods are still very much a viable solution. In fact they may be combined with fuzzy logic to produce a dynamically changing system. The validation of a fuzzy logic system can be difficult due to the fact that it is a nonformal system. Its use in safety systems should be considered with care. </p> <p>I hope this short article will inspire the exploration and use of fuzzy logic in some of your future designs. I encourage the reader to do further study on the subject. There are numerous books and articles that go into much more detail. This serves as a simple introduction to fuzzy logic controls. </p> <p>&#8211; Norm Dingle is a senior system engineer with EMP Technical Group of Noblesville, IN. He holds a BSE from Purdue University. </p> <p><a href="https://emptechgroup.com/" target="cfeTarget">www.emptechgroup.com</a>&nbsp;</p> <p><a href="https://www.ni.com/en-us.html" target="cfeTarget">www.ni.com</a>&nbsp;</p> <p>Design trends in PLC-based control systems </p> <p>Designing Your Own Control System </p> <p>Nonlinear control: All you wanted to know about fuzzy logic </p> <p class="contribute-link-container">Do you have experience and expertise with the topics mentioned in this content? You should consider contributing to our CFE Media editorial team and getting the recognition you and your company deserve. Click <a href="https://controleng.dragonforms.com/loading.do?omedasite=brandContributor&pk=CE" target="_blank" title="How to Contribute" alt="How to Contribute">here</a> to start this process.</p> <script>
    StackExchange.ready(function () {
        StackExchange.Hero.init("nso", "a");

        var location = 0;
        if ($("body").hasClass("questions-page")) {
            location = 1;
        } else if ($("body").hasClass("question-page")) {
            location = 1;
        } else if ($("body").hasClass("faq-page")) {
            location = 5;
        } else if ($("body").hasClass("home-page")) {
            location = 3;
        }

        $('.js-cta-button').click(function () {
            StackExchange.using("gps", function () {
                StackExchange.gps.track("hero.action", { hero_action_type: 'cta', location: location }, true);
            });
        });

        // TODO: we should review the class names and whatnot in use here. Older heroes use id selectors, the newer
        // sticky question hero on SO has a .js-dismiss class instead, but it's apparently not used anywhere... 
        // It's not great. Ideally we'd have a set of classes in the partials above that would correspond to 
        // the behaviours we want here in a more clear way. 

        // sticky question-page hero at the bottom of the page on SO
        $('.js-dismiss').on('click', function () {
            StackExchange.using("gps", function () {
                StackExchange.gps.track("hero.action", { hero_action_type: "close", location: location }, true);
            });
            StackExchange.Hero.dismiss();
            $(".js-dismissable-hero").fadeOut("fast");
        });
    });
</script>

        <div id="content" class="">

            

<div itemprop="mainEntity" itemscope itemtype="https://schema.org/Question">
    <link itemprop="image" href="https://cdn.sstatic.net/Sites/ai/Img/apple-touch-icon.png?v=f14d741b295c">

    <div class="inner-content clearfix">

        

            <div id="question-header" class="d-flex sm:fd-column">
                        <h1 itemprop="name" class="fs-headline1 ow-break-word mb8 flex--item fl1"><a href="/questions/4176/are-there-real-applications-of-fuzzy-logic" class="question-hyperlink">Are there real applications of fuzzy logic?</a></h1>
                <div class="ml12 aside-cta flex--item print:d-none sm:ml0 sm:mb12 sm:order-first sm:as-end">
                        <a href="/questions/ask" class="ws-nowrap s-btn s-btn__primary">
        Ask Question
    </a>

                </div>
            </div>
            <div class="d-flex fw-wrap pb8 mb16 bb bc-black-075">
                    <div class="flex--item ws-nowrap mr16 mb8" title="2017-10-03 09:42:23Z">
                        <span class="fc-light mr2">Asked</span>
                        <time itemprop="dateCreated" datetime="2017-10-03T09:42:23">4 years, 11 months ago</time>
                    </div>
                    <div class="flex--item ws-nowrap mr16 mb8">
                        <span class="fc-light mr2">Modified</span>
                        <a href="?lastactivity" class="s-link s-link__inherit" title="2020-03-03 18:10:25Z">2 years, 6 months ago</a>
                    </div>
                    <div class="flex--item ws-nowrap mb8" title="Viewed 12,906 times">
                        <span class="fc-light mr2">Viewed</span>
                        13k times
                    </div>
            </div>
            <div id="mainbar" role="main" aria-label="question and answers">

                
<div class="question js-question" data-questionid="4176" data-position-on-page="0" data-score="5"  id="question">
    <style>
    </style>
<div class="js-zone-container zone-container-main">
    <div id="clc-tlb" class="everyonelovesstackoverflow everyoneloves__top-leaderboard everyoneloves__leaderboard"></div>
		<div class="js-report-ad-button-container " style="width: 728px"></div>
</div>

    <div class="post-layout">
        <div class="votecell post-layout--left">
            <div class="js-voting-container d-flex jc-center fd-column ai-stretch gs4 fc-black-200" data-post-id="4176">
        <button class="js-vote-up-btn flex--item s-btn s-btn__unset c-pointer "

        </button>



    
        <a class="js-post-issue flex--item s-btn s-btn__unset c-pointer py6 mx-auto" href="/posts/4176/timeline" data-shortcut="T" data-ks-title="timeline" data-controller="s-tooltip" data-s-tooltip-placement="right" title="Show activity on this post." aria-label="Timeline"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="mln2 mr0 svg-icon iconHistory" width="19" height="18" viewBox="0 0 19 18"><path d="M3 9a8 8 0 1 1 3.73 6.77L8.2 14.3A6 6 0 1 0 5 9l3.01-.01-4 4-4-4h3L3 9Zm7-4h1.01L11 9.36l3.22 2.1-.6.93L10 10V5Z"/></svg></a>

</div>

        </div>

        

<div class="postcell post-layout--right">
    <span class="d-none">$\begingroup$</span>
    <div class="s-prose js-post-body" itemprop="text">
                
<p><a href="https://ai.stackexchange.com/questions/10/what-is-fuzzy-logic">This question</a> covers in detail, what fuzzy logic is and how it relates to other math fields, such as boolean algebra and sets theory.</p>

<p><a href="https://ai.stackexchange.com/questions/118/how-can-fuzzy-logic-be-used-in-creating-ai">This question</a> is also very related, but the answers are focused more on general intuition and <em>potential</em> applicability. The only working system based on fuzzy logic, mentioned there, is <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mycin" rel="noreferrer">MYCIN</a>, which goes back to the early 70s. This quote from wiki summarizes my impression of it:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>MYCIN was never actually used in practice.</p>
</blockquote>

<p>From my experience in AI, the best tool to deal with uncertainty is <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_probability" rel="noreferrer">Bayesian probability</a> and inference. It allows to apply not only a wide range of probabilistic tools, such as expectation, MLE, cross-entropy, etc, but also calculus and algebra.</p>

<p>Can you call fuzzy logic a "pure theoretical" concept, which only played its role in the early development of AI? Are there real practical applications of fuzzy logic? What problem would you recommend to solve and to <em>code</em> using fuzzy logic?</p>
    </div>

        <div class="mt24 mb12">
            <div class="post-taglist d-flex gs4 gsy fd-column">
                <div class="d-flex ps-relative fw-wrap">

                </div>
            </div>

<a name="4230"></a>
<div id="answer-4230" class="answer js-answer accepted-answer js-accepted-answer" data-answerid="4230" data-parentid="4176" data-score="2" data-position-on-page="1" data-highest-scored="0" data-question-has-accepted-highest-score="0"  itemprop="acceptedAnswer" itemscope itemtype="https://schema.org/Answer">
    <div class="post-layout">
        <div class="votecell post-layout--left">
            <div class="js-voting-container d-flex jc-center fd-column ai-stretch gs4 fc-black-200" data-post-id="4230">
        <button class="js-vote-up-btn flex--item s-btn s-btn__unset c-pointer "
                data-controller="s-tooltip"

                <div class="ta-center">
                    <svg aria-hidden="true" class="svg-icon iconCheckmarkLg" width="36" height="36" viewBox="0 0 36 36"><path d="m6 14 8 8L30 6v8L14 30l-8-8v-8Z"/></svg>

            </div>

    
        <a class="js-post-issue flex--item s-btn s-btn__unset c-pointer py6 mx-auto" href="/posts/4230/timeline" data-shortcut="T" data-ks-title="timeline" data-controller="s-tooltip" data-s-tooltip-placement="right" title="Show activity on this post." aria-label="Timeline"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="mln2 mr0 svg-icon iconHistory" width="19" height="18" viewBox="0 0 19 18"><path d="M3 9a8 8 0 1 1 3.73 6.77L8.2 14.3A6 6 0 1 0 5 9l3.01-.01-4 4-4-4h3L3 9Zm7-4h1.01L11 9.36l3.22 2.1-.6.93L10 10V5Z"/></svg></a>

        </div>

        

<div class="answercell post-layout--right">
    <span class="d-none">$\begingroup$</span>
    <div class="s-prose js-post-body" itemprop="text">
<p>Fuzzy logic seems to have multiple of applications historically in Automotive Engineering.  </p>

<p>I found an interesting article on the subject from 1997. This excerpt provides an interesting rationale:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>The key reason for fuzzy logic’s success in automotive engineering lies in the implications of its paradigm shift. Previously, engineers spent much time creating mathematical models of mechanical systems. More time went to real-world road tests that tuned the fudge factors of the control algorithms. If they succeeded, they ended up with a control algorithm of mathematical formulas involving many experimental parameters. Modifying or later optimizing such a solution is very difficult because of its lack of transparency. Fuzzy logic makes this design process faster, easier, and more transparent. It can implement control strategies using elements of everyday language. Everyone familiar with the control problem can read the fuzzy rules and understand what the system is doing and why. It also works for control systems with many control parameters. Designers can build innovative control systems that would have been intractable using traditional design techniques. <br><sub>SOURCE: <a href="ftp://ftp.me.psu.ac.th/pub/me/Fuzzy/88constantin.pdf" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Fuzzy Logic in
  Automotive Engineering</a>, 1997</sub></p>
</blockquote>

<p><br>Here are some papers and patents for automatic transmission control in motor vehicles. One of them is fairly recent: </p>

<p><a href="http://papers.sae.org/930674/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Automatic Transmission Shift Schedule Control Using Fuzzy Logic</a> <br><sub>SOURCE: Society of Automotive Engineers, 1993</sub></p>

<p><a href="http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00423119508969099?journalCode=nvsd20" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Fuzzy Logic in Automatic Transmission Control</a> <br><sub>SOURCE: International Journal of Vehicle Mechanics and Mobility, 2007</sub></p>

<p><a href="http://ipasj.org/IIJCS/Volume2Issue7/IIJCS-2014-06-24-3.pdf" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Fuzzy Logic Based Controller For Automated
Gear Control in Vehicles</a> <br><sub>SOURCE: International Journal of Computer Science, 2014</sub></p>

<p><a href="https://www.google.com/patents/US4841815" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Fuzzy control system for automatic transmission</a> | Patent | 1987</p>

<p><a href="https://www.google.com/patents/US5390117" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Transmission control with a fuzzy logic controller</a> | Patent | 1992</p>

<p><br> </p>

<p>Likewise with fuzzy logic anti-lock breaking systems (ABS):</p>

<p><a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_sie.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Antilock-Braking System and Vehicle Speed Estimation using Fuzzy Logic</a> <br><sub>SOURCE: FuzzyTECH, 1996</sub></p>

<p><a href="https://www.ijser.org/researchpaper/FUZZY-LOGIC-ANTI-LOCK-BRAKE-SYSTEM.pdf" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Fuzzy Logic Anti-Lock Break System</a> <br><sub>SOURCE: International Journal of Scientific &amp; Engineering Research, 2012</sub></p>

<p><a href="https://www.google.com/patents/US5416709?dq=fuzzy%20logic%20abs&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwiV8dOaguLWAhUHLSYKHbtQC18Q6AEIKDAA" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Fuzzy controller for anti-skid brake systems</a> | Patent | 1993</p>

<p><br> </p>

<p>This method seems to have been extended to aviation:</p>

<p><a href="http://aix.acad.ro/sectii2002/proceedings/doc2_2004/12_Ursu.pdf" rel="nofollow noreferrer">A Fuzzy Logic Control Synthesis for an Airplane Antilock-Breaking System</a> <br><sub>SOURCE: Proceedings of the Romanian Academy, 2004</sub></p>

<p><a href="https://www.google.com/patents/US8955793?dq=fuzzy%20logic%20abs&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=0ahUKEwiV8dOaguLWAhUHLSYKHbtQC18Q6AEIVDAG" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Landing gear method and apparatus for braking and maneuvering</a> | Patent | 2003</p>

<p><br></p>
    </div>
    <div class="mt24">

<a name="4178"></a>
<div id="answer-4178" class="answer js-answer" data-answerid="4178" data-parentid="4176" data-score="4" data-position-on-page="2" data-highest-scored="1" data-question-has-accepted-highest-score="0"  itemprop="suggestedAnswer" itemscope itemtype="https://schema.org/Answer">
    <div class="post-layout">
        <div class="votecell post-layout--left">
            <div class="js-voting-container d-flex jc-center fd-column ai-stretch gs4 fc-black-200" data-post-id="4178">
        <button class="js-vote-up-btn flex--item s-btn s-btn__unset c-pointer "

        </div>

            <div class="js-accepted-answer-indicator flex--item fc-green-700 py6 mtn8 d-none" data-s-tooltip-placement="right" title="Loading when this answer was accepted&#x2026;" tabindex="0" role="note" aria-label="Accepted">
                <div class="ta-center">
                    <svg aria-hidden="true" class="svg-icon iconCheckmarkLg" width="36" height="36" viewBox="0 0 36 36"><path d="m6 14 8 8L30 6v8L14 30l-8-8v-8Z"/></svg>
                </div>
            </div>

    
        <a class="js-post-issue flex--item s-btn s-btn__unset c-pointer py6 mx-auto" href="/posts/4178/timeline" data-shortcut="T" data-ks-title="timeline" data-controller="s-tooltip" data-s-tooltip-placement="right" title="Show activity on this post." aria-label="Timeline"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="mln2 mr0 svg-icon iconHistory" width="19" height="18" viewBox="0 0 19 18"><path d="M3 9a8 8 0 1 1 3.73 6.77L8.2 14.3A6 6 0 1 0 5 9l3.01-.01-4 4-4-4h3L3 9Zm7-4h1.01L11 9.36l3.22 2.1-.6.93L10 10V5Z"/></svg></a>

        </div>

        

<div class="answercell post-layout--right">
    <span class="d-none">$\begingroup$</span>
    <div class="s-prose js-post-body" itemprop="text">
<p>You've obviously never heard of <a href="http://www.samsung.com/in/support/skp/faq/138486" rel="nofollow noreferrer">fuzzy logic washing machines</a>.</p>

<blockquote>
  <p>● Typically, fuzzy logic controls the washing process, water intake,water temperature, wash time, rinse performance, and spin speed. This optimises the life span of the washing machine. More sophisticated machines weigh the load (so you can’t overload the washing machine), advise on the required amount of detergent, assess cloth material type and water hardness, and check whether the detergent is in powder or liquid form. Some machines even learn from past experience,memorising programs and adjusting them to minimise running costs. </p>
</blockquote>

<p>Fuzzy logic is used in a variety of control applications.  If your furnace can only be on or off, for example, you might use a probabilistic function of temperature to determine when to turn it on and off, rather than having fixed high and low temperatures activate your thermostat.  In some applications, that's been found to improve perceived comfort or efficiency.</p>

<p>For more sophisticated AI applications, you could use fuzzy logic for activations in a neural net, but I don't think it's offering much improvement over fixed, weighted activations.</p>
    </div>
    <div class="mt24">
        <div class="d-flex fw-wrap ai-start jc-end gs8 gsy">
            <time itemprop="dateCreated" datetime="2017-10-03T15:48:13"></time>
            <div class="flex--item mr16" style="flex: 1 1 100px;">

<div class="answercell post-layout--right">
    <span class="d-none">$\begingroup$</span>
    <div class="s-prose js-post-body" itemprop="text">
<p>The site <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/" rel="nofollow noreferrer">FuzzyTECH</a> lists an array of applications:</p>

<blockquote>
  <p><a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_plc.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Industrial Automation</a> <br> 
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_glc.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Monitoring Glaucoma</a> <br> 
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_htw.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Coal Power Plant</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_kli.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Complex Chilling Systems</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_mull.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Refuse Incineration Plant</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_eet.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Fuzzy Logic Design</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_pfd.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Practical Design</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_dek.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Water Treatment System</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_spe.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Truck Speed Limiter</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_med.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Medical Shoe</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_med.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Fuzzy in Appliances</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_esw.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Automotive Engineering</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_sie.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Antilock Braking System</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_ap_afp.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Aircraft Flight Path</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_ap_nfu.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Nucluar Fusion</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_mot.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Motorla 68HC12 MCU</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_tfc.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Traffic Control</a> <br>
  <a href="http://www.fuzzytech.com/e/e_a_kumm.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Sonar Systems</a></p>
</blockquote>

<p>Most of the linked articles have good bibliographies citing numerous papers, although it's notable that most of the material is a few decades old.</p>
    </div>

<a name="18398"></a>
<div id="answer-18398" class="answer js-answer" data-answerid="18398" data-parentid="4176" data-score="1" data-position-on-page="4" data-highest-scored="0" data-question-has-accepted-highest-score="0"  itemprop="suggestedAnswer" itemscope itemtype="https://schema.org/Answer">
    <div class="post-layout">
        <div class="votecell post-layout--left">
            <div class="js-voting-container d-flex jc-center fd-column ai-stretch gs4 fc-black-200" data-post-id="18398">
        <button class="js-vote-up-btn flex--item s-btn s-btn__unset c-pointer "
                data-controller="s-tooltip"
                data-s-tooltip-placement="right"
                title="This answer is useful"
                aria-pressed="false"
                aria-label="Up vote"
                data-selected-classes="fc-theme-primary"
                data-unselected-classes="">
            <svg aria-hidden="true" class="svg-icon iconArrowUpLg" width="36" height="36" viewBox="0 0 36 36"><path d="M2 25h32L18 9 2 25Z"/></svg>
        </button>
        <div class="js-vote-count flex--item d-flex fd-column ai-center fc-black-500 fs-title"
             itemprop="upvoteCount"
             data-value="1">
            1
        </div>
        <button class="js-vote-down-btn flex--item s-btn s-btn__unset c-pointer "
                data-controller="s-tooltip"
                data-s-tooltip-placement="right"
                title="This answer is not useful"
                aria-pressed="false"
                aria-label="Down vote"
                data-selected-classes="fc-theme-primary"
                data-unselected-classes="">
            <svg aria-hidden="true" class="svg-icon iconArrowDownLg" width="36" height="36" viewBox="0 0 36 36"><path d="M2 11h32L18 27 2 11Z"/></svg>
        </button>



            <div class="js-accepted-answer-indicator flex--item fc-green-700 py6 mtn8 d-none" data-s-tooltip-placement="right" title="Loading when this answer was accepted&#x2026;" tabindex="0" role="note" aria-label="Accepted">
                <div class="ta-center">
                    <svg aria-hidden="true" class="svg-icon iconCheckmarkLg" width="36" height="36" viewBox="0 0 36 36"><path d="m6 14 8 8L30 6v8L14 30l-8-8v-8Z"/></svg>

        <a class="js-post-issue flex--item s-btn s-btn__unset c-pointer py6 mx-auto" href="/posts/18398/timeline" data-shortcut="T" data-ks-title="timeline" data-controller="s-tooltip" data-s-tooltip-placement="right" title="Show activity on this post." aria-label="Timeline"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="mln2 mr0 svg-icon iconHistory" width="19" height="18" viewBox="0 0 19 18"><path d="M3 9a8 8 0 1 1 3.73 6.77L8.2 14.3A6 6 0 1 0 5 9l3.01-.01-4 4-4-4h3L3 9Zm7-4h1.01L11 9.36l3.22 2.1-.6.93L10 10V5Z"/></svg></a>

</div>

        </div>

        

<div class="answercell post-layout--right">
    <span class="d-none">$\begingroup$</span>
    <div class="s-prose js-post-body" itemprop="text">
<p>Recently, I needed to develop a Fuzzy Logic algorithm to made inferences of any data entrance; the real case applied was in Oil and Gas Industry, that the code needs to infere Joint Types in Fluid Pipelines. But with this Algorithm, the Computer Science Developer can infere any problems data, follow the link bellow:</p>

<p><a href="https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/5092762/Csharp-Fuzzy-Logic-API" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/5092762/Csharp-Fuzzy-Logic-API</a> (<em>C# Fuzzy Logic API</em>)</p>
    </div>
    <div class="mt24">
        <div class="d-flex fw-wrap ai-start jc-end gs8 gsy">
            <time itemprop="dateCreated" datetime="2020-03-03T18:10:25"></time>
            <div class="flex--item mr16" style="flex: 1 1 100px;">

Sidebar: Inline"),s.pubads().setTargeting("Sidebar",["Inline"])),"dfp-tsb"===t&&(e.cM("-> targeting - Sidebar: Right"),s.pubads().setTargeting("Sidebar",["Right"]));const{path:i,sizes:o,zone:r}=(0,a.Z7)(t);e.cM(`Defining slot for ${t}: ${i}, sizes: ${JSON.stringify(o)}`),s.defineSlot(i,o,t).addService(s.pubads())}importGptLibrary(){this.gptImported||(this.gptImported=!0,void 0===this.opt.targeting_consent||this.opt.targeting_consent?(0,i.Gx)("https://securepubads.g.doubleclick.net/tag/js/gpt.js"):(0,i.Gx)("https://pagead2.googlesyndication.com/tag/js/gpt.js"))}isGptReady(){return"undefined"!=typeof googletag&&!!googletag.apiReady}initGpt(){this.isGptReady()||(window.googletag={cmd:(0,i.QZ)(()=>this.importGptLibrary())})}initDebugPanel(t,s){e.cM("initDebugPanel"),e.cM("Not showing debug panel")}}})()})();</script><script type="text/javascript">
    var cam = cam || {};
    if (typeof cam.opt === 'undefined') {
        cam.opt = {};
    }
    var opt = cam.opt;


    opt.sf = !1;
    opt.hb = !1;
    opt.ll = !0;
    opt.tlb_position = 0;
    opt.targeting_consent = !1;
    opt.performance_consent = !1;

    opt.targeting = {Registered:['false'],'ron-tag':['ai-design','applications','problem-solving','fuzzy-logic'],NumberOfAnswers:['4']};
    opt.adReportEnabled = !1;
    opt.adReportUrl = '/ads/report-ad';
    opt.adReportText = 'Report this ad';
	opt.adReportFileTypeErrorMessage = 'Please select a PNG or JPG file.';
	opt.adReportFileSizeErrorMessage = 'The file must be under 2 MiB.';
	opt.adReportErrorText = 'Error uploading ad report.';
	opt.adReportThanksText = 'Thanks for your feedback. We&#x2019;ll review this against our code of conduct and take action if necessary.';
    opt.adReportLoginExpiredMessage = 'Your login session has expired, please login and try again.';
    opt.adReportLoginErrorMessage = 'An error occurred when loading the report form - please try again';
	opt.adReportModalClass = 'js-ad-report';

        opt.targeting.PromotedContent = 'udemydtod2022';
        opt.targeting.PromotedId = '113742';
        opt.targeting.QuestionId = '4176';
        opt.targeting.PromotedHost = 'ai.stackexchange.com';

    opt.targeting.TargetingConsent = ['False_Passive'];

    const urlParams = new URLSearchParams(window.location.search);
    if (urlParams.has('dfptestads')) {
        const dfptestads = urlParams.get('dfptestads');
        opt.targeting.DfpTestAds = dfptestads;
    }

    var googletag = googletag || {};
    googletag.cmd = googletag.cmd || [];
    googletag.cmd.push(function () { cam.load(); });
</script>

data-category=social_sharing_copylink data-action=copylink_share_link_clicks><img src=https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/themes/edu-new/img/feather_link.png alt="image not found!"><span class="tooltiptext copy_text sticky_copy">Copy Link!</span></a></div><div class="blogs-navigation border-top text-center color-4a"> <a href=https://www.edureka.co/blog/introduction-to-markov-chains/ class="btn no-shadow "><i class=icon-Blog-left-arrow></i></a><span class=current-blog>4</span> / <span class=total-blogs>7 </span>Blog from <span class=blog-category>Statistical Inference</span> <a href=https://www.edureka.co/blog/bayesian-networks/ class="btn no-shadow "><i class=icon-Blog-right-arrow></i></a></div></section></div><hr class=responsive-divider> <a class=open-leftbar><i class=icon-blog-bookmark></i></a><div class="blog-content mt-md-4 mt-lg-4 mt-xl-4 color-4a"><div class=btn-become-professional-link> <a href=https://www.edureka.co/machine-learning-and-ai class="btn become-professional-btn-resp become-professional-link" data-course-title="Post Graduate Diploma in Artificial Intelligence Course"> Become a Certified Professional<i class=icon-blog-right-arrowsvg></i></a></div><p style="text-align: justify;">In our day to day life, we might face situations where we are unable to determine whether the state is true or false. Fuzzy refers to something which is unclear or vague. Fuzzy Logic in AI provides valuable flexibility for reasoning. And in this article, we will learn about this logic and its implementation in <a rel="noopener noreferrer" href=https://www.edureka.co/ai-deep-learning-with-tensorflow target=_blank>Artificial Intelligence</a> in the following sequence:</p><ul> <li><a href=#fuzzy>What is Fuzzy Logic?</a></li> <li><a href=#why>Why do we use Fuzzy Logic?</a></li> <li><a href=#architecture>Architecture</a></li> <li><a href=#member>Membership Function</a></li> <li><a href=#probability>Fuzzy Logic vs Probability</a></li> <li><a href=#applications>Applications of Fuzzy Logic</a></li> <li><a href=#advantage>Advantages &amp; Disadvantages</a><a name=fuzzy></a></li> <li><a href=#example>Fuzzy Logic in AI: Example</a></li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><h2><strong>What is Fuzzy Logic?</strong></h2><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Fuzzy Logic</strong> (FL) is a method of reasoning that resembles <strong>human reasoning</strong>. This approach is similar to how humans perform decision making. And it involves all intermediate possibilities between <strong>YES</strong> and <strong>NO</strong>.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><img class="aligncenter wp-image-123338 size-large" src=/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/fuzzy-logic-427x300.png alt="fuzzy logic - fuzzy logic in AI - edureka" width=427 height=300 srcset="https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/fuzzy-logic-427x300.png 427w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/fuzzy-logic-150x105.png 150w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/fuzzy-logic-300x211.png 300w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/fuzzy-logic-768x540.png 768w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/fuzzy-logic-256x180.png 256w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/fuzzy-logic.png 1056w" sizes="(max-width: 427px) 100vw, 427px"></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The <strong>conventional logic block</strong> that a computer understands takes precise input and produces a definite output as TRUE or FALSE, which is equivalent to a human being&#8217;s YES or NO. The Fuzzy logic was invented by <strong>Lotfi Zadeh</strong> who observed that unlike computers, humans have a different range of possibilities between YES and NO, such as:</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><img class="aligncenter wp-image-123294 size-thumbnail  lazyload blur-up " src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAMLCwgAAACH5BAAAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAICRAEAOw==" data-src=https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture1-1-137x150.png alt="possibilities - fuzzy logic in AI - edureka" width=137 height=150 data-srcset="https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture1-1-137x150.png 137w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture1-1-165x180.png 165w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture1-1.png 249w" data-sizes="(max-width: 137px) 100vw, 137px"></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The Fuzzy logic works on the levels of possibilities of input to achieve a definite output. Now, talking about the implementation of this logic:</p><ul> <li><p style="text-align: justify;"><a name=why></a>It can be implemented in systems with different sizes and capabilities such as <strong>micro-controllers, large networked</strong> or <strong>workstation-based systems.</strong></p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">Also, it can be implemented in <strong>hardware, software</strong> or a combination of <strong>both</strong>.</p> </li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><h2><strong>Why do we use Fuzzy Logic?</strong></h2><p style="text-align: justify;">Generally, we use the fuzzy logic system for both commercial and practical purposes such as:</p><ul> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">It <strong>controls machines</strong> and <strong>consumer products</strong></p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">If not accurate reasoning, it at least provides <strong>acceptable reasoning</strong></p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">This helps in dealing with the <strong>uncertainty in engineering</strong></p> </li></ul><p style="text-align: justify;"><a name=architecture></a>So, now that you know about Fuzzy logic in AI and why do we actually use it, let&#8217;s move on and understand the architecture of this logic.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><h2><strong>Fuzzy Logic Architecture</strong></h2><p>The fuzzy logic architecture consists of four main parts:</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><img class="aligncenter wp-image-123302 size-full  lazyload blur-up " src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAMLCwgAAACH5BAAAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAICRAEAOw==" data-src=https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture2.png alt="architecture - fuzzy logic in AI - edureka" width=1890 height=874 data-srcset="https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture2.png 1890w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture2-150x69.png 150w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture2-300x139.png 300w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture2-768x355.png 768w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture2-528x244.png 528w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture2-389x180.png 389w" data-sizes="(max-width: 1890px) 100vw, 1890px"></p><p>&nbsp;</p><ul> <li><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Rules</strong> &#8211; It contains all the rules and the if-then conditions offered by the experts to control the decision-making system. The recent update in the fuzzy theory provides different effective methods for the design and tuning of <strong>fuzzy controllers</strong>. Usually, these developments reduce the number of fuzzy rules.</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Fuzzification</strong> &#8211; This step converts inputs or the crisp numbers into fuzzy sets. You can measure the crisp inputs by sensors and pass them into the<strong> control system</strong> for further processing. It splits the input signal into five steps such as-</p> </li></ul><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-123323  lazyload blur-up " src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAMLCwgAAACH5BAAAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAICRAEAOw==" data-src=https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2019-12-09-14_13_08-Window-300x162.png alt width=300 height=162 data-srcset="https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2019-12-09-14_13_08-Window-300x162.png 300w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2019-12-09-14_13_08-Window-150x81.png 150w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2019-12-09-14_13_08-Window-333x180.png 333w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2019-12-09-14_13_08-Window.png 368w" data-sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px"></strong></p><ul> <li><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Inference Engine</strong> &#8211; It determines the degree of match between fuzzy input and the rules. According to the input field, it will decide the rules that are to be fired. Combining the fired rules, form the control actions.</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Defuzzification</strong> &#8211; The Defuzzification process converts the fuzzy sets into a crisp value. There are different types of techniques available, and you need to select the best-suited one with an expert system.</p> </li></ul><p style="text-align: justify;"><a name=member></a>So, this was about the architecture of fuzzy logic in AI. Now, let&#8217;s understand the membership function.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><h2><strong>Membership Function</strong></h2><p style="text-align: justify;">The membership function is a <strong>graph</strong> that defines how each point in the <strong>input space</strong> is mapped to membership value between 0 and 1. It allows you to <strong>quantify linguistic terms</strong> and represent a fuzzy set graphically. A membership function for a fuzzy set A on the universe of discourse X is defined as <strong>&mu;A:X &rarr; [0,1]</strong></p><p style="text-align: justify;">It quantifies the degree of membership of the element in X to the fuzzy set A.</p><ul> <li><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>x-axis</strong> represents the universe of discourse.</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>y-axis</strong> represents the degrees of membership in the [0, 1] interval.</p> </li></ul><p style="text-align: justify;">There can be multiple membership functions applicable to fuzzify a numerical value. Simple membership functions are used as the complex functions do not add precision in the output. The membership functions for <strong>LP, MP, S, MN, and LN</strong> are:</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><img class="aligncenter wp-image-123369 size-large  lazyload blur-up " src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAMLCwgAAACH5BAAAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAICRAEAOw==" data-src=https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture4-528x234.png alt width=528 height=234 data-srcset="https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture4-528x234.png 528w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture4-150x66.png 150w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture4-300x133.png 300w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture4-768x340.png 768w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture4-406x180.png 406w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Picture4.png 1872w" data-sizes="(max-width: 528px) 100vw, 528px"></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">The triangular membership function shapes are most common among various other membership function shapes. Here, the input to 5-level fuzzifier varies from <strong>-10 volts to +10 volts</strong>. Hence the corresponding output also changes.<a name=probability></a></p><p>&nbsp;</p><h2><strong>Fuzzy Logic vs Probability</strong></h2><p>&nbsp;</p><table style="width: 804px;" border="1px solid black"><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center; width: 402px;"><strong>Fuzzy Logic</strong></td><td style="text-align: center; width: 402px;"><strong>Probability</strong></td></tr><tr><td style="width: 402px;">In fuzzy logic, we basically try to capture the essential concept of vagueness.</td><td style="width: 402px;">Probability is associated with events and not facts, and those events will either occur or not occur</td></tr><tr><td style="width: 402px;">Fuzzy Logic captures the meaning of partial truth</td><td style="width: 402px;">Probability theory captures partial knowledge</td></tr><tr><td style="width: 402px;">Fuzzy logic takes truth degrees as a mathematical basis</td><td style="width: 402px;">Probability is a mathematical model of ignorance</td></tr></tbody></table><p style="text-align: justify;"><a name=applications></a>So, these were some of the differences between fuzzy logic in AI and probability. Now, let&#8217;s have a look at some of the applications of this logic.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><h2><strong>Applications of Fuzzy Logic</strong></h2><p style="text-align: justify;">The Fuzzy logic is used in various fields such as automotive systems, domestic goods, environment control, etc. Some of the common applications are:</p><ul> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">It is used in the <strong>aerospace field</strong> for<strong> altitude control</strong> of spacecraft and satellite.</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">This controls the <strong>speed and traffic</strong> in the<strong> automotive systems.</strong></p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">It is used for <strong>decision making support systems</strong> and personal evaluation in the large company business.</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">It also controls the pH, drying, chemical distillation process in the <strong>chemical industry</strong>.</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">Fuzzy logic is used in <strong>Natural language processing</strong> and various intensive <a rel="noopener noreferrer" href=https://www.edureka.co/blog/artificial-intelligence-applications/ target=_blank>applications in Artificial Intelligence</a>.</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">It is extensively used in <strong>modern control systems</strong> such as expert systems.</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">Fuzzy Logic mimics how a person would make decisions, only much faster. Thus, you can use it with <a rel="noopener noreferrer" href=https://www.edureka.co/blog/what-is-a-neural-network/ target=_blank>Neural Networks</a>.</p> </li></ul><p style="text-align: justify;"><a name=advantage></a>These were some of the common applications of the Fuzzy Logic. Now, let&#8217;s have a look at the advantages and disadvantages of using Fuzzy Logic in AI.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><h2><strong>Advantages &amp; Disadvantages of Fuzzy Logic</strong></h2><p style="text-align: justify;">Fuzzy logic provides simple reasoning similar to human reasoning. There are more such <strong>advantages</strong> of using this logic, such as:</p><ul> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">The structure of Fuzzy Logic Systems is <strong>easy and understandable<img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-123370  lazyload blur-up " src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAMLCwgAAACH5BAAAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAICRAEAOw==" data-src=https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/adv-300x279.jpg alt width=300 height=279 data-srcset="https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/adv-300x279.jpg 300w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/adv-150x139.jpg 150w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/adv-768x714.jpg 768w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/adv-323x300.jpg 323w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/adv-194x180.jpg 194w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/adv.jpg 1056w" data-sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px"></strong></p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">Fuzzy logic is widely used for <strong>commercial</strong> and <strong>practical purposes</strong></p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">It helps you to <strong>control machines</strong> and consumer products</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">It helps you to deal with the <strong>uncertainty in engineering</strong></p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">Mostly <strong>robust</strong> as no precise inputs required</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">If the feedback sensor stops working, you can <strong>program it</strong> into the situation</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">You can<strong> easily modify</strong> it to improve or alter system performance</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Inexpensive sensors</strong> can be used which helps you to keep the overall system cost and complexity low</p> </li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">These were the different advantages of fuzzy logic. But, it has some <strong>disadvantages</strong> as well:</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-74506  lazyload blur-up " style="text-align: justify;" src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAMLCwgAAACH5BAAAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAICRAEAOw==" data-src=https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-265x300.png alt="disadvantages - fuzzy logic in AI - edureka" width=265 height=300 data-srcset="https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-265x300.png 265w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-132x150.png 132w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-768x870.png 768w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1-159x180.png 159w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Picture1.png 1808w" data-sizes="(max-width: 265px) 100vw, 265px"></p><ul> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">Fuzzy logic is <strong>not always accurate</strong>. So the results are perceived based on assumptions and may not be widely accepted</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">It <strong>cannot recognize</strong> <a rel="noopener noreferrer" href=https://www.edureka.co/blog/introduction-to-machine-learning/ target=_blank>machine learning</a> as-well-as <a rel="noopener noreferrer" href=https://www.edureka.co/blog/neural-network-tutorial/ target=_blank>neural network</a> type patterns</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;"><strong>Validation and Verification</strong> of a fuzzy knowledge-based system needs <strong>extensive testing</strong> with hardware</p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">Setting exact, fuzzy rules and, membership functions is a <strong>difficult task</strong></p> </li> <li><p style="text-align: justify;">At times, the fuzzy logic is <strong>confused</strong> with <strong>probability theory</strong></p> </li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><a name=example></a>So, these were some of the advantages and disadvantages of using fuzzy logic in AI. Now, let&#8217;s take a real-world example and understand the working of this logic.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><h2><strong>Fuzzy Logic in AI: Example</strong></h2><p style="text-align: justify;">The design of a fuzzy logic system starts with a set of membership functions for each input and a set for each output. A set of rules is then applied to the membership functions to yield a crisp output value. Let&#8217;s take an example of process control and understand fuzzy logic.</p><h3><strong>Step 1</strong></h3><p style="text-align: justify;">Here, <strong>Temperature</strong> is the input and <strong>Fan Speed</strong> is the output. You have to create a set of membership functions for each input. A membership function is simply a graphical representation of the fuzzy variable sets. For this example, we will use three fuzzy sets, <strong>Cold, Warm</strong> and <strong>Hot</strong>. We will then create a membership function for each of three sets of temperature:</p><h3><strong><img class="aligncenter wp-image-123372 size-large  lazyload blur-up " src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAMLCwgAAACH5BAAAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAICRAEAOw==" data-src=https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-1-528x264.png alt width=528 height=264 data-srcset="https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-1-528x264.png 528w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-1-150x75.png 150w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-1-300x150.png 300w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-1-768x384.png 768w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-1-360x180.png 360w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-1.png 1611w" data-sizes="(max-width: 528px) 100vw, 528px"></strong></h3><p>&nbsp;</p><h3><strong>Step 2</strong></h3><p style="text-align: justify;">In the next step, we will use three fuzzy sets for the output, <strong>Slow, Medium</strong> and <strong>Fast</strong>. A set of functions is created for each output set just as for the input sets.</p><p><img class="aligncenter wp-image-123373 size-large  lazyload blur-up " src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAMLCwgAAACH5BAAAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAICRAEAOw==" data-src=https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-2-528x264.png alt width=528 height=264 data-srcset="https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-2-528x264.png 528w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-2-150x75.png 150w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-2-300x150.png 300w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-2-768x384.png 768w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-2-360x180.png 360w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-2.png 1611w" data-sizes="(max-width: 528px) 100vw, 528px"></p><p>&nbsp;</p><h3><strong>Step 3</strong></h3><p style="text-align: justify;">Now that we have our membership functions defined, we can create the rules that will define how the membership functions will be applied to the final system. We will create three rules for this system.</p><ul> <li><strong>If Hot then Fast</strong></li> <li><strong>If Warm then Medium</strong></li> <li><strong>And, if Cold then Slow</strong></li></ul><p>&nbsp;</p><p><img class="aligncenter wp-image-123374 size-large  lazyload blur-up " src="data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAMLCwgAAACH5BAAAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAICRAEAOw==" data-src=https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-3-528x182.png alt width=528 height=182 data-srcset="https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-3-528x182.png 528w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-3-150x52.png 150w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-3-300x103.png 300w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-3-768x264.png 768w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-3-524x180.png 524w, https://d1jnx9ba8s6j9r.cloudfront.net/blog/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/step-3.png 1949w" data-sizes="(max-width: 528px) 100vw, 528px"></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p style="text-align: justify;">These rules apply to the membership functions to produce the crisp output value to drive the system. Thus, for an input value of <strong>52 degrees</strong>, we intersect the membership functions. Here, we are applying two rules as the intersection occurs on both functions. You can extend the intersection points to the output functions to produce an intersecting point. You can then truncate the output functions at the height of the intersecting points.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">This was a very simple explanation of how the fuzzy logic systems work. In a real working system, there would be many inputs and the possibility of several outputs. This would result in a fairly complex set of functions and many more rules.</p><p style="text-align: justify;">With this, we have come to the end of our Fuzzy Logic in AI article. I hope you understood what is fuzzy logic and how it works.</p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Also, check out the<span>&nbsp;</span><a rel="noopener noreferrer" href=https://www.edureka.co/ai-deep-learning-with-tensorflow target=_blank><strong>AI and Deep Learning with TensorFlow</strong></a><span>&nbsp;</span>Course&nbsp;is curated by industry professionals as per the industry requirements &amp; demands. You will master the concepts such as SoftMax function, Autoencoder Neural Networks, Restricted Boltzmann Machine (RBM) and work with libraries like Keras &amp; TFLearn. The course has been specially curated by industry experts with real-time case studies.&nbsp;</em></p><p style="text-align: justify;"><em>Got a question for us? Please mention it in the comments section of &ldquo;Fuzzy Logic in AI&rdquo; and we will get back to you.</em></p></div><div class=course_info_blog_re><div class=title>Upcoming Batches For Post Graduate Diploma in Artificial Intelligence Course</div><table style="width:100% !important;border-radius: 5px;"><tr><th>Course Name</th><th>Date</th><th></th></tr><tr><td class=course_title><a href="https://www.edureka.co/executive-programs/machine-learning-and-ai?utm_source=blogbatch&utm_campaign=batch_details">Post Graduate Diploma in Artificial Intelligence Course</a></td><td class=course_info><p class=desktop_class><span>Class Starts on </span>8th October,2022</p><p class=mobile_class><span></span>8th October</p>SAT&SUN (Weekend Batch)</td><td class=course_redirect><a href="https://www.edureka.co/executive-programs/machine-learning-and-ai?utm_source=blogbatch&utm_campaign=batch_details">View Details</a></td></tr><script type=application/ld+json>{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"EducationEvent","name":"Post Graduate Diploma in Artificial Intelligence Course","description":"Upskill yourself with the world's top-rated Post Graduate Diploma in AI and Machine Learning. Article</a></div></div></div><div class="col-xl-4 col-lg-4 col-12 item"><div class=recommended-article-tile><a href=https://www.edureka.co/blog/introduction-to-apache-mahout/
